content.heading: Essential Comma Rules
content.text: Commas create pauses and separate elements, making your writing clearer and easier to follow.

concept_box.title: The Big 4 Comma Uses
points: üìù **Lists** - Separate items in a series (red, white, and blue)

examples.correct: After studying for hours, Maria, who was determined to succeed, felt confident about the exam.
examples.incorrect: After studying for hours Maria who was determined to succeed felt confident about the exam.

elements.trigger: Click to see comma placement breakdown
elements.reveal: Notice: comma after intro (After studying), commas around non-essential info (who was determined), and proper flow throughout.

content.heading: Strategy: Systematic Punctuation Check

strategy_steps.title: PAUSE - Find natural breaks
strategy_steps.description: Read aloud to hear where pauses naturally occur
strategy_steps.example: The student studied hard (pause) and she passed the test.

strategy_steps.title: ANALYZE - Identify clause types
strategy_steps.description: Determine if clauses are independent or dependent
strategy_steps.example: Independent: 'The student studied hard' + 'she passed' = comma + conjunction

strategy_steps.title: CONNECT - Choose appropriate punctuation
strategy_steps.description: Select commas, semicolons, or colons based on relationship
strategy_steps.example: Related ideas of equal weight = semicolon; explanation = colon

strategy_steps.title: EDIT - Remove unnecessary marks
strategy_steps.description: Eliminate excess punctuation that doesn't serve a purpose
strategy_steps.example: Avoid comma overload that makes sentences choppy

content.memory_aid: Keep a good **P.A.C.E.** for clear punctuation!

slides.title: Semicolons and Colons: The Power Players

content.heading: Advanced Punctuation Tools
content.text: Semicolons and colons add sophistication and clarity to your writing when used correctly.

concept_box.title: Semicolon vs. Colon
points: üîÑ **Semicolon (;)** - Connects related independent clauses of equal weight
üìã **Before lists** - Use semicolons when list items contain commas
üí° **After complete thought** - Colons must follow independent clauses

examples.semicolon: The experiment failed; however, the data was still valuable.
examples.colon: The recipe requires three main ingredients: flour, eggs, and milk.

elements.reveal: Semicolon = partial stop (like a comma with more power). Colon = full stop before explanation (like a period that introduces).

passage.text: The students notebooks were scattered across the librarys tables. Its important to note that the books pages showed signs of heavy use, and many students couldnt find there favorite study spots. The teachers dedication to helping student's succeed was evident in the extra time she spent reviewing everyones work.

guided_questions.question: Find and fix the POSSESSION errors
guided_questions.hint: Look for ownership that needs apostrophes
guided_questions.answer: students' notebooks, library's tables, books' pages
guided_questions.explanation: Plural possessives (students', books') get apostrophes after the s. Singular possessives (library's) get apostrophe before s.

guided_questions.question: Identify CONTRACTION vs. POSSESSIVE errors
guided_questions.hint: Its vs. It's, there vs. they're
guided_questions.explanation: It's = it is, their = possessive pronoun (no apostrophe), couldn't = could not.

guided_questions.question: Fix the final apostrophe error
guided_questions.explanation: 'Students' here is plural, not possessive. 'Everyone's' is possessive and needs an apostrophe.

passage.text: The companys new policy affects all employees however some workers arent sure about it's implementation. The managers explanation was clear: all departments must follow the same procedures and everyone's input is valued during the transition.

question.text: Which choice correctly punctuates the passage?
options: The company's new policy affects all employees; however, some workers aren't sure about its implementation. The manager's explanation was clear: all departments must follow the same procedures, and everyone's input is valued during the transition.

The companys new policy affects all employees, however, some workers aren't sure about it's implementation. The managers explanation was clear: all departments must follow the same procedures and everyones input is valued during the transition.

The company's new policy affects all employees, however some workers aren't sure about it's implementation. The manager's explanation was clear; all departments must follow the same procedures, and everyone's input is valued during the transition.

The companies new policy affects all employees; however some workers arent sure about its implementation. The managers explanation was clear: all departments must follow the same procedures and everyones input is valued during the transition.

explanations.A: ‚úì Correct! All apostrophes and punctuation are properly placed: company's (possessive), semicolon before however, aren't (contraction), its (possessive pronoun), manager's (possessive), colon before explanation, everyone's (possessive).
explanations.B: Incorrect apostrophe usage: 'it's' should be 'its' (possessive), missing apostrophes in 'companys', 'managers', 'everyones', and comma splice with 'however'.
explanations.C: Wrong punctuation around 'however' (should be semicolon, not comma), and 'it's' should be 'its'.
explanations.D: Multiple errors: 'companies' should be 'company's', missing apostrophes, 'arent' should be 'aren't', and 'everyones' should be 'everyone's'.

key_points.title: Comma Essentials

key_points.title: Apostrophe Rules

strategy_card.title: Punctuation Quick Reference
tips: Commas: lists, joining, setting off, after intros
Apostrophes: possession + contractions, not possessive pronouns

common_mistakes: Confusing its/it's and other possessive pronouns
Using commas around 'however' instead of semicolons
Overusing commas or using them incorrectly
